nodes.title: Security and Privacy meeting agenda for 2023-03-06
nodes.body:
Meeting Details
Date/Time: March 6th, 2023 @ Monday 1:00 PM ET / 18:00 UTC / 7:00 PM CET
Moderator: lesssneaky
Note Taker Person
The [FIG Security and Privacy Meetings](https://github.com/Open-MV/fig-security/tree/main/meetings) repo contains the history past meetings, including a link to the agenda, recording, notes, and resources.

Meeting Agenda
Package management & supply chain options
check-in on #users discussion

Outcomes from Discussion topics
Discuss outcomes from agenda

Action Items
Create actionable items from proposed topics

Items for next week's meeting
List items that need to be discussed next week

Open Discussion Items
List any additional items below!

Quick summarization on the rust crates research I performed last week:
* It looks like we can sync crates.io to github teams, that way we can properly permission folks natively within GitHub: https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/publishing.html
* Doing the GitHub team-based approach makes this safer administratively, as added owners cannot remove other owners (although they can still yank/publish packages).
* We will still need to have an OMF-level account. Perhaps we can look into a 1password instance for OMF administrators.

Does using OIDC work well from a security perspective? From conversation in user channel, summarised on hedgedoc: https://hedgedoc.openmv.org/s/rAFOZRsyd

Current consensus is “we like OIDC but need to fix issues X Y and Z”
Reference: https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc4949
And there seems to be general agreement on using OIDC terms for the root node (identity) and the digitally trackable unique persona (scope). Further, this scope could likely be based on a ‘traits’ system on identities; A player logs in on a world, sends over its identity with its traits, and the world can just pick out the ones it is actually interested in

- Send your authentication scope to the auth server, and if it succeeds and the platform provider lets you in, send the appropriate actor scope
- I think we can make some pretty good ‘proof of history’ system that could let us provide automated spam protection while avoiding penalizing legitimate users

fix issues X,Y and Z has to do with:
Like OpenID Connect (OIDC): you don’t know how the identity is verified but you know where to check it (it is currently possible to set up an OIDC provider that lets you verify exclusively by signing a challenge with a private key, if you so choose)
- “Ironically I think for OIDC to really take off in a democratized way you’d need something like a trusted store – basically the spot that CAs occupy in the TLS model – but without it being so hard to add a new trusted CA.”
- The way OIDC does this is by piggybacking on DNS and keychains, which is working alright with some issues.
I’d prefer a scheme similar to that, but without DNS’ domain squatting issues and overall cryptography issues
- The idea being some kind of managed system for linking internet resources to specific identifiers that can recover from data loss and attacks through moderation by a trusted party

03-03-2023

Users discussion:
* Considering OIDC
    * We would have to fix a few issues
        * Mostly comes down to a few DNS/crypto issues
        * Some adaptation would be needed
    * One challenge is adoption — it doesn’t have much
    * We may be able to fork it to address our concerns
    * Lift this discussion into a debate thread (AI for Indie)
DB entries:
* Lets switch to first half DB entries, second half updates on prior work
    * We should consider doing this as community as well

            * Link @helbakoury

## Meeting Details
Date/Time: February 13th, 2023 @ Monday 1:00 PM ET / 18:00 UTC / 7:00 PM CET
Moderator: lesssneaky
Note Taker Person: lesssneaky

## Meeting Agenda
- First meeting and operating
- FIG charter discussion
- Database Feature triage

## Meeting notes

* What is our FIG's operating model?
    * A lot of the work happens within other FIGs (e.g. #users with IAM discussions)
        * We could look at an embedded model
        * Lift security-related discussions to the FIG for review & collaboration
* IAM & Governance is a core area that needs to be done right, as nearly everything revolves around this.
    * We have a lot of discussions around _users_ (these discussions also align with what we have within our feature database so far)
        * Authentication (e.g. who/what is something)
        * Authorization of resources (e.g. what can/can't something do)
        * Confidentiality controls (e.g. selective disclosure of something's descriptors)
        * Data silos (e.g. storage of something's experience-relevant data)
    * We need to have similar discussions around the governance of _experiences_ (e.g. the "administrator" perspective; these are not accounted for within our feature database right now)
        * How do we expose controls to creators to govern their experiences?
        * How do we allow users to be informed about the governance controls they are operating within?
    * We need to partner with the legal-privacy FIG to help evaluate regulatory concerns 
        * We can partner with FIGs to incorporate solutions into core implementations
* Technical guidance is something we might want to get out in front of
    * We could provide guidance on implementation preferences when it comes to common security controls
        * Some arbitrary (and arguable) examples: 
            * Whenever possible, default to TLS
            * Whenever possible, use a memory-safe language (e.g. Go, Rust, etc)
            * Avoid re-implementation of cryptographic primitives
         * This guidance could allow us to operationalize mitigations over time (e.g. templated linters/static analysis/etc) and allow out-of-the-loop oversight 

## Action Items
1. Poll to determine our FIGs operating model
2. Evaluate how we can best support the #users FIG with designing the identity model (from both the perspective of the "user" and "administrator")
3. Engage with the #legal-policy FIG to discuss wide-scope regulatory concerns, and start mapping those out to relevant FIGs for collaboration on the granular details
4. Evaluate areas and methodologies for technical guidance
